projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

figure.head: MRS. CENTLIVRE.
figure.byline: • . S • rmin pinx. • Tayl • r sculp.

div.p: A WIFE WELL MANAG'D. A FARCE.
LONDON: Printed and Sold by S. Keimer, at the Printing-Preſs in Pater-Noſter-Row. 1715

list.head: MEN.
list.label: DON Piſalto,
list.item: Deſigned to have been reprefented by Mr. Norris.
list.label: Father Bernardo.
Teague.

div.head: ACT I. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: AH, Inis! My Indiſpoſition is not to be cur'd.

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: Not without applying the proper Medicine I grant ye.—Well, had I ſuch a Confeſſor as Father Bernardo—I ſay no more—but I ſancy nothing wou'd trouble my Conſcience long.

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: My Meaning depends upon yours, Madam; pray what do you mean by painting Farther Bernardo's Picture in every Room in the Houſe, at your Beds-head, your Toilet, at the Bottom of your Crucifix, at every Corner of your Handkerchief, nay upon your very Fan too, as if the Good Father, like the Traveller in the Fable, cou'd heat and cool at once?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Is there any harm in wearing a good Man's Picture? Is he not one of the Pillars of our Church? Eminent for de claiming againſt Heriſy and Schiſm, and fain wou'd reconcile the World to Rome s pure Religion? Oh they are bleſt that he Converts, happy the Pair, who e'er they be, that are in Wedlock joyn'd by him. Wou'd I had been one of thoſe.

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: If the Good Father has this healing Art, Why are you uneaſy? A little of his comfortable Conſolation wou'd revive the Colour in thoſe Cheeks, and give great Satiſfaction to your Mind, or I have loſt my Judgment, and I don't uſe to be out in my Gueſs, where Love's the Riddle.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Well, ſince thou haſt hit my Diſtemper ſo exactly, Girl, I'll confeſs ingeniouſly to thee, I do love Father Bernardo to Diſtraction, but how to diſcover my Paſſion, or what Reception it may meet with when diſcover'd, is that which wracks me.

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p:
A kind one I warrant you, Madam: For tho' Prieſts are forbid to marry, as a mortal Sin, Fornication was never reckon'd
more than Venial; and for Diſcovery, whilſt there's Pen, Ink, and Paper in the World, a Woman can never be at a loſs to tell her Mind. Write to him Madam, write to him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But who ſhall carry it?

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: Your Iriſh Footman; he's a ſimple honeſt Fellow, and may eaſily be manag'd; do you write your Letter, Madam, and I'll give him Inſtructions in the mean Time.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I'll do it this Minute.

div.stage: (Inis goes to the Door and calls, Teague▪

sp.speaker: Teague.
sp.p: Well Mrs. Inis; What Commands have you for Teague now?

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: Do you think you can do a Meſſage cunningly, Teague?

sp.speaker: Teague.
sp.p: Cunningly! Yes Faith, we are all ſo cunning now—What for a Meſſage is it?

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: It is a Letter for Father Bernardo at the Convent of St. Francis; if you do it handſomly, a Moider is your Reward; do you hear, but if you make any Miſtake—

sp.speaker: Teague.
sp.p: Hub, bub, bub, bu, Miſtake! No Faith won't I, Arra! An will you be after giving me the Moider indeed, and by my Shoul now?

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: Upon Honour.—

sp.speaker: Teague.
sp.p: Arra, ſay no more now—I will be here agen in a Quarter of an Hour.

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: But you muſt ſtay for the Letter, Teague.

sp.speaker: Teague.
sp.p:
No, no, 'tis no Matter; I have a
very clean Letter in my Pocket which will do very well, upon my Shoul. (going) and ſave Time, yes Faith will it.

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: Ha ha; no, no, Teague, that won't do; come along with me, and I'll give you the Letter; but if you ſhou'd meet my Maſter Don Piſalto, not a Word of the Letter for your Life—And I charge you to give it into no Hands but the Prieſts, and bring me an Anſwer, and then the Moider is your own.

sp.speaker: Teague.
sp.p: Faith will I.—

sp.speaker: Teague.
sp.p: Arra, pon my Shoul, I have forgot this plaguy Prieſt's Name—Yes Faith have I—Father Bom, Bom, Bom,—By St. Patrick I don't know who to ask for now—Arra, What ſhall I do?—Who the Devil ſhall I get to read the Outſide of this Letter now?

div.stage: Enter Don Piſalto behind him, and looks over his Shoulder on the Letter.

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: For Father Bernardo.

sp.speaker: Tea.
sp.p: Oh, pon my Shoulvation dat is the Name now. (turns quick upon Don Piſalto. Ha, my Maiſtre! What ſhall I ſay now,

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: Whither are you going with that Letter Sirrah? It is my Wives Hand,

sp.speaker: Tea.
sp.p:
Ha ha, pon my Shoul, a very good
Jeſt, firſt reads the Direction, and then asks me whither it goes.

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: It may not prove ſo good a Jeſt as you think Sirrah—Who gave you that Letter?

sp.speaker: Tea.
sp.p: Arra Maiſtre, you are very uncivil now to enquire into other Folks Buſineſs, ſo you are, yes Faith are you.

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: I ſhall be ſo very uncivil to break your Head Raſcal, if you don't anſwer me to the Purpoſe; give me the Letter you Dog you.

sp.speaker: Tea.
sp.p: Faith won't I—That's the Way to loſe the Moider, which I am to have for carrying it.

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: A Moider for carrying it! Sure the Buſineſs muſt be very urgent, when the Poſtage is ſo dear. Give it me, I ſay, or or,

sp.speaker: Tea.
sp.p: No pon my Shoul won't I.

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: Won't you Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Tea.
sp.p: Arra, take the Letter (throws it down) Pox upon me, if I don't wiſh the Devil had you both, yes Faith do I; for poor Teague loſes his Moider now, and Mrs. Inis will never ſend me of no more Arrands, no Faith won't ſhe.

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: Inis, Ho! Did ſhe give it you—

sp.speaker: Tea.
sp.p: Yes indeed now, and I believe there is ſome very great Sin in the Letter now, that the Good Father was to ſend his Pardon for, ſo I do.

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p:
Monſtrous! What do I ſee? Yes here is a Sin with a Witneſs— (Reads) Dear Father, you'll forgive me when I tell you, that the more I ſee you, the more I hate my Husband, (very fine) and the more I pray againſt Temptation, the more powerfully my Inclinations plead in your Behalf, (Furies and Diſtraction,)—I implore your charitable Aſſiſtance to conquer this unruly Sin— (Yes I'll help you with a Vengance to you)—Nothing but your Company can prolong the Life of Flora.
(Say you ſo Miſtreſs? Very well. Inis gave you this Letter you ſay!

sp.speaker: Tea.
sp.p: Yes Faith did ſhe—Arra dear honny Maiſtre, an you have don with the Letter give it now, that I may carry it to the Good Father, what de ye call him, or I ſhall loſe the Moider, yes Faith ſhall I.

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: Ha! A lucky Thought comes into my Head, and this Fellows Simplicity is of uſe: Hark ye, Teague, come you along with me, I am acquainted with Father Bernardo, I'll procure you an Anſwer to this Letter—It is as you ſay, a Letter of Confeſſion, and I believe Inis might not perform Articles with you, if ſhe knew I had ſeen it; but take you no Notice of that, do you hear—And there is two Moiders for you Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Tea.
sp.p: Oh. by my Shoul Teague is dumb—Now I ſhall have three Moiders; Faith this is a lucky beating for poor Teague; now will I drink St. Patrick's Health till I am as red as a Potato, yes Faith will I

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: I have had very odd Dreams to Night; methought I was in Bed with Lady Piſalto—Ah, wou'd it was true, for ſhe is a charming Woman; by St. Anthony I never hear her Confeſſion, but my Virtue is much ſtagger'd; the Fleſh and Spirit hold ſtrong Contention; Oh, ſhe's a delicious Morſel.
Ha! Her Husband, I hope did not overhear me.

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: So, I have diſpatch'd the Iriſhman. Ha! Father Bernardo, well met; I was going to your Convent, I have a Favour to ask of you.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: You command me, Senior, Piſalto, pray what is it?

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: Why I muſt deſire you to procure me a Habit of your Order for an Hour or two.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: I hope you have no Enterprize in View, that may ſcandalize the Prieſthood.

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: Fy, fy, does a Man of my Years give you Room for Suſpicion? Beſides, I am a married Man you know.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: And to the moſt beautiful Lady in Madrid—A Religious, Virtuous Lady; Ah, you are a happy Man, Senior.

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p:
A Curſe of the Happineſs—Her Virtue, and your Sanctity, Father, might have begot a Monſter, call'd a Cuckold, if Fortune
had not flung me in the Way to prevent it.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: What ſay you, Senior!

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: I ſay I am contented, Father.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Contented! Why another Man wou'd be tranſported, raviſh'd, nay almoſt guilty of Idolatry.

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: Humph! There wou'd have been fine Work if they had come together; Oh, theſe Prieſts are full of Abſtinence, and Piety! (Aſide) If you'll oblige me with a Habit, let it be immediately, and I ſhou'd be proud if you'd give me your Company this Evening to ſup with my Wife and I; I'll aſſure you Father, ſhe has a profound Reſpect for you.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: I am much oblig'd to her, Senior, I'll not fail to accept your kind Invitation, come along with me and I'll give you the Habit.—A profound Reſpect for me—Oh, that it were Love.

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: I'll ſend for them this Minute, Father, but now I muſt pay a Viſit to my virtuous Wife, and ſee how ſhe bears her Expectation.
sp.l: 'Mongſt all the Ills which clogg this Mortal Life,
The moſt acurſt, and verieſt Plague is—Wife.

div.head: SCENE Changes.
div.stage: Enter Lady reading a Letter; Inis following.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
He has anſwer'd me as I cou'd wiſh—Dear, dear Inis, how ſhall I reward thee?
Take that in Earneſt of my future Kindneſs, he ſays he will come in the Twilight, which will ſoon be here, tho' not ſo ſoon as I cou'd wiſh it:—He deſires, for Reaſons which he will give me, he ſays, to be admitted in the Dark, which caution does not diſpleaſe me, ſince it will prevent the Confuſion I ſhou'd be in after ſuch a Declaration.—

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: He did that on purpoſe, Madam; he is a true Cavalier, and underſtands his Buſineſs to a Hair; he knows Darkneſs is neceſſary upon rheſe Occaſions; it prevents a Lady's Bluſhes.—Ods heart, Madam, here's my Lord, I hear him cough.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh miſchevious Minute;—Here, here, run down the back Stairs, and burn that Letter immediately.
I'll to my Book.

div.stage: (Sits down, and takes up a Book.

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: There ſhe ſits,—as if ſhe knew nothing of the Matter,—a Cockatrice,—What always at thy Devotion, Figgup?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: How can I paſs my Time better in your Abſence, Pudſey? Were it not for theſe good Books, I ſhou'd be very melancholy, when you are from me, Pudſey.

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: Hell confound her for a deſembling Witch.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What ails my Pudſey? You look out of Humour with your nown Figgup, What have I done, ha?

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: Nothing yet I hope;—But that's no Fault of hers.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Nay, what are you ſtudying for, Pud, ha!

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: Why if you muſt know, little Figgey,—then I'll tell thee; Don Cammaray lays claim to Part of that Eſtate I bought laſt Year, and I muſt he oblig'd to leave my dear Figgup for two or three Hours this Evening, in order to conſult my Lawyers about that Matter, that's all Figgey;—And I was afraid thou ſhould'ſt take it ill of thy nown Pud.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Lucky beyond Expreſſion: (Aſide) No, no, Pud, I am not ſo unreaſonable neither;—I can divert my ſelf with my Books till thy return.—But do Puddey—make all the Haſte you can to your nown Figgup—

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: Ay, ay, more haſte than you'd wiſh I dare ſwear. (Aſide) That I will my Precious.—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What never a parting Kiſs, Pudſey? Oh you don't love your Figgup! Go, go, you are a naughty Hubby;—I I I I wiſh I cou'd love you leſs than I do, ſo I do.

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: Did ever Woman make a Cuckold with a better Grace? Ounds ſhe outdoes an Engliſh Wife.—Nay don't weep Figgup; I'll ſtay with thee, let the Eſtate go how it will, rather than diſpleaſe my little Figgey.—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Heaven forbid, that wou'd be carrying the Jeſt too far. (Aſide) No, no, I don't deſire that, Pud.

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: No, I dare ſwear it.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Go, but give me a kind Kiſs firſt, Pudſey.

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: Ah you are a coaxing Baggage.
Well, Good by Figgey.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Good by Pudſey—with all my Heart.
He is gone Girl moſt fortunately.

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: I overheard all, and wiſh you Joy of this lucky Opportunity,—Come, come, Madam, away to your Chamber, 'tis near the Time,—and there contemplate on your coming Joy; whilſt I, your Harbinger of Bliſs, wait to conduct the Man that is to crown your Happineſs.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I fly, I fly Girl.

div.head: SCENE changes, and diſcovers Lady Piſalto leaning on a Couch.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Bleſs me, what Noiſe was that!—My Heart akes horridly leſt this old Cuff ſhou'd return and prevent my charming Prieſt.

div.stage: Enter Inis, leading in Don Piſalto in a Prieſt's Habit.

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: Fear nothing, Father, ſtrait forward is your Way to Happineſs.

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: A Happineſs, I fear, will bode ſomebody no Good. Hiſt, hiſt, Daughter! Where are you?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Ha! He's come,—here, here, my too charming Father, can you forgive a Woman's Weakneſs—

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: Common Frailties of Fleſh and Blood, (groping about) if thou haſt pray'd againſt it, thou haſt done thy Part, and we are bound to comfort thoſe that faint.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh, I have often pray'd, Father, but to no Purpoſe; you are the only Object of my Wiſhes, I bluſh, tho' in the Dark, to own how much I love you.—

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: Come to my Arms, and hide thoſe Bluſhes in my Boſom. (they meet and embrace) Is your Husband ſafe▪

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Safe enough, tho' long he will not ſtay, Fortune ſmil'd upon my Wiſhes, and call'd him luckily abroad.—

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: Then let us improve the little Time we have; thus let me cool the raging Feaver in your Blood.

div.stage: (Catches hold of her Arm, and pulls out a Ropes End and beats her ſoundly, ſhe roars out all the while.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh! What do you mean, to murder me? Inhumane Monſter! Oh! Murder, Murder, Murder,—oh, oh, oh,

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: Bleſs me! What's the Matter, Madam?

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: Only adminiſtring a little Penance, Miſtreſs; it won't be amiſs to beſtow a little Charity upon you too.

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: The Devil take you, and your Penance too, you old ſanctify'd Dog you: Thieves, Thieves; I'll have you equip'd for the Opera, Sarrah, I will ſo: A Light there a Light, here's Thieves in the Houſe—Oh, oh, Murder, Thieves,—my Lady's murder'd.—

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: I muſt not ſtay for a Light, leaſt they diſcover who I am:—One farewel Stroke—And now remember your Benefactor, Miſtreſs Bawd.

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: Yeſs, I ſhall remember with a Vengeance.

sp.speaker: Tea.
sp.p: Arra by my Shoul what is de Matter now? Is de Houſe haunted? Has de great Devil and de little Devil put de Fright upon you both together now?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Begon impertinent Fool.

sp.speaker: Tea.
sp.p: Fool! Pon my Shoul Iriſhman are no Fools;—By St. Patrick, we make Fools of de very great many Engliſh, yes Faith and of de Spaniards too.

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: Get out Sirrah, or I'll fling the Candle at your Head.

sp.speaker: Tea.
sp.p: Arra, Pox take your ugly Face, and him that wou'd put a Kiſs upon't, for Teague.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh, I am kill'd Inis! This curſed Prieſt has kill'd me.

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p:
Was there ever ſuch a Monſter? I dare ſwear I am black from Head to Foot, he laid on moſt unmercifully:—Well my Mind
miſgives me, this Prieſt is no Man, this feels like an occaſional Correction.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Occaſional, do you call it? I'm ſure he has given me occaſion to remember it this Twelve-Month.

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: Figgup, why Figgup—where are you Child?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Ah Heaven, my Husband's Voice—return'd ſo ſoon! What ſhall I ſay for my Indiſpoſition?

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: Oh Invention! Where art thou?

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: What, aſleep little Figgy?

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: Aſleep, Senior, no, no, alas my poor Lady had like to have been kill'd ſince you went.

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: Kill'd! As how? You make me tremble.

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: Going down Stairs, her Foot ſlipt, and down ſhe tumbled from Top to Bottom, and bruiz'd her ſelf ſo ſadly, that ſhe is not able to ſtir a Finger; it is a Mercy ſhe was not kill'd out right.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Excellent Wench.

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: Here's a pure Jade at Invention.—They ſay the Devil's a Lyar, but I'll be hang'd if this Wench won't out-lye the Devil.—I'm heartily ſorry for this Misfortune, poor dear Figgy;—but I hope thou haſt not broke any Bones, my dear Figgup?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But I am much hurt, Pudſey.

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: I'm ſorry for't, for I have invited Father Bernardo to ſup wirh us; I met him hard by here, and brought him back with me,—becauſe I know he is a Favourite with my Figgy.

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: Not ſo great a Favorite as he was, if you knew all.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I beg you wou'd excuſe me, Pudſey, I cannot come down, beſides I have no Stomach.

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: No! The Prieſt has given her and me Supper enough, more than we can digeſt this Twelve-month.

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: Well, if thou can'ſt not eat, there's no more to be ſaid. Take Care of your Lady, Inis.—We'll drink thy Health little Figgup.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: My Heart riſes at the Villain, if I ſhou'd ſee him, I think in my Soul I ſhould tear his Eyes out; Oh that I cou'd be reveng'd.

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: Reveng'd! What Revenge cou'd you take bad enough, Madam? 'Tis impoſſible to find Revenge equal to the Affront; A Ropes End to a Lady that expected!—I cou'd flea him alive, ſo I cou'd.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: My Head akes greiveouſly.

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: Let me cover you up upon the Bed, Madam, a little Sleep will Settle your Head agen.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Your Lady poſſeſt ſay you?

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: 'Tis even ſo Father, I left her well, and ſound in her Senſes, I thought, about Two Hours ago; but now ſhe raves, calls Names, Fights, and talks of being beat by every Body that comes near her.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Poor Lady, I am exceeding ſorry, I'll take Care ſhe ſhall be pray'd for by the whole Convent.

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: I wiſh you wou'd ſee her Father, perhaps your Ghoſtly Admonition might do her good. Men of your Holy Function have Power over unclean Spirits; pray try what you can do for her.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Withal my Heart, but I have no Holy Water about me;—nothing frights the Devil like Holy Water,—thence comes the Proverb, you know.

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: I can help you to ſome, pleaſe to walk this Way, Father.

div.head: SCENE changes, and diſcovers Lady Piſalto on a Couch, aſleep.
div.stage: Enter Prieſt, ſets a Baſon of Water on the Table,—Don Piſalto liſtning.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p:
Peace be here—Ha! She ſleeps:—How invitingly ſhe lies? Why what a delicious
Morſel has this old ſapleſs Long every Night to ſnoar over.

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: Well ſaid Prieſt;—Oh this is a Holy Man; no Wonder he's the Women's Favourite.—

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: I feel a ſtrange Diſorder on the Suddain,—my Pulſe beats quick, and every Senſe ſeems raviſh'd at this Object.—Ha! We are alone,—What hinders me to make uſe of the Opportunity?—

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: Zounds, I ſhall be Cuckolded before my Face.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Beſides, none dare to preſs upon our Privacy,—we have that Advantage above the Laity, I'll try; if ſhe ſhould prove virtuous, and reſiſt, the Noiſe will paſs upon her Husband, as the Effect of her Poſſeſſion, for I ſhrewdly ſuſpect, ſhe is not mad indeed, and only puts it on to avoid the Embraces of that Skeleton, unfit for a Woman of her Youth and Fire.

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: Well, for a thorough pac'd Whoremaſter, commend me to a Prieſt, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: I'll try I'm reſolv'd.

div.stage: (Steals ſoftly to the Couch and kiſſes her.

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: Very well,—Zounds, I ſhan't contain my ſelf.—

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Rapture! Her very Lips gives Extaſie!—She ſleeps very ſound—once more,

div.stage: (Goes to kiſs her again, and ſhe lifts up her Eyes and ſees him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
I dreamt! Ha! Bleſs me, the Monſter's
here! Oh that I could look him dead.—

div.stage: (Going to riſe, Bernardo ſtops her, and kneels.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Oh do not riſe my charming Angel, let me feaſt my Eyes upon that lovely Face, the perfect Image of the Bleſt above.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Do not inſult me, thou ungrateful Traytor! Do not.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: What means my Charmer? Oh forgive my raſh Proceeding, and blame your Eyes, thoſe dear bewitching Eyes, for all that I have done.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Off Monſter, Devil, worſe, if worſe can be, than Devil, thou very Prieſt.—

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: Excellent, it works now as I wou'd have it.—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You thought you had kill'd me, I ſuppoſe,—but you ſhall find, I live to tear your Eyes out, Monſter.

div.stage: (Flys up and pulls his Hood off, and beats him.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Help, Help, Help, bleſs me! She is really poſſeſt.

sp.speaker: Iris.
sp.p: Ha! You here agen, Old Belzebub! but I'll be even with you now, I will ſo.

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: Ha, ha, I ſhall dye with Laughing.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: What do you mean Madam, pray be calm, I wou'd comfort you.

sp.speaker: Iris.
sp.p:
As how pray Father; I am much
miſtaken if you have any Thing that can comfort a Lady.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Oh Wickedneſs! Have I nothing that can comfort a Lady?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Yes Villain, I can ſhow your Marks of Comfort, I can ſo; but I'll be reveng'd on thee, I will.

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: Yes, and I can ſhow 'em too; this for my Lady, this for my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: Ha, ha, O rare Figgup, O rare Inis.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Bleſs me! By St. Anthony they are both poſſeſt, the Maid has caught her Frenzy too, in Nomine Domine.—

div.stage: (Runs to the Table, and catches up the Holy-Water and flings, firſt on one, then on the other.

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: Ha, ha, O rare Prieſt, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I'll Nomine Domine you, you had better have hang'd your ſelf in your Rope's End, than have uſed it about me, I'll make it a dear beating to you, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Oh Maria Mater ora pro nobis.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Ah! He'll drown me.—

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Avant Sathan, I conjure thee, by St. Anthony, St. Bridget, and our Lady of Loretta.

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.stage: (Strikes down the Baſon and breaks it.)
sp.p:
—What, hoa, A Rape, A Rape, I'll cant you, I'll have you hang'd;—I'll ſhew the World the Jewel they doat on: I ſaw you when you
wou'd have raviſh'd my Lady,—thou Monſter of Iniquity.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Mercy on me, the Devil is very ſtrong in them both.

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: Ha, ha, I muſt releaſe the Prieſt, or they'll murder him between them.—Oh the Rage of a diſappointed Woman.—What's the Matter here? Pray Father withdraw, I am heartily ſorry for your ill Treatment, it is their height of Frenzy you ſee Father; I'll wait upon you in the next Room immediately, you can do them no Good I ſee, Father.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Alas Senior, they are ſo ſtrongly poſſeſt that no one Man can deal with them both.

sp.speaker: Inis.
sp.p: Will you let him go Senior, why he wou'd have raviſh'd my Lady, if I had not cry'd out.

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: No Miſtreſs, you cry'd out becauſe he had not raviſh'd your Lady.—Go troop Miſtreſs, I ll reckon with you within. (Exit Inis. And now Madam for you.—Do you know this Letter?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Ha! My Letter to Father Bernardo! the Villain has betray'd me!—and I'm undone!

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: Why don't you anſwer me? What, are you dumb? Then I muſt fetch you to your Speech with this.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Ah! Defend me Heaven. (falls on her Knees.) But why name I Heaven;—I have offended that in wronging you, tho' but in Thought;—Oh forgive me, have Pity on my Youth, and let me live, puniſh me as ſeverely as you pleaſe, let even him who has betray'd me, name my Penance, and then I'm ſure it will be harſh enough, what e'er it be, I will perform it moſt religiouſly.

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: I melt,—the cunning Baggage knows her Power.—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh! Do Pudſey do, won't you forgive your nown Figgup, can you pierce this Boſom you have kiſs'd ſo often, and ſee your Figgeys Blood run trickling down?—

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: I am conquer'd, I can hold no longer.—Riſe Figgup, for this Time I will forgive thee; but on Condition you ne'er ſee your Ghoſtly Father more, no more Harrangues in Praiſe of his Sanctity, and Holyneſs of Life; Do you hear, Figgey?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: No never indeed, Pudſey.

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.p: Take heed, for if again I catch you faulty, look to it, expect no Pardon.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: No, when I am, may I your Pardon miſs,
Since you ſo generouſly forgive me this.

sp.speaker: Don Piſ.
sp.l: When Wives like mine gives Inclination Scope,
No Cure for Cuckoldom like Oyl of Rope.
